natural problem: Find the minimum value of $x^6 + y^6 - 54xy$ over all real numbers $x$ and $y.$
natural solution: Suppose $xy$ is negative. If we flip the sign of $y,$ then we flip the sign of $xy,$ which makes it positive. This increases by the value of $x^6 + y^6 + xy,$ so if $x^6 + y^6 + xy$ is minimized, then $xy$ must be positive.
We may assume that both $x$ and $y$ are positive.

By AM-GM, \[\frac{x^6 + y^6 + 27 + 27 + 27 + 27}{6} \ge \sqrt[6]{(x^6)(y^6)(27^4)} = 9xy,\]which simplifies to $x^6 + y^6 - 54xy \ge -108.$ Equality occurs when $x^6 = y^6 = 27,$ which leads to $x = y = \sqrt{3}.$  Therefore, the minimum value is $\boxed{-108}.$

theorem
fixes x y :: real and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. P x y = x powr 6 + y powr 6 - 54*x*y"
shows  "P x y \<ge> -108"

 *)
